TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . She is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON .
The respondent Government were represented by their Agent , Mr P. ORG , succeeded by PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant claimed an increase in maintenance which her father had been earlier ordered to pay to her . At that time the applicant ’s father held the post of Vice - President of the PERSON - okolie ORG .
On DATE the ORG heard the applicant ’s mother with a view to establishing whether the applicant , then under age , acted through her intermediary .

CARDINAL judges of the Košice II District Court dealing with similar issues considered themselves biased as they knew the defendant . On DATE the case - file was therefore submitted to ORG with a view to determining whether the ORG judges were to be excluded .
ORG judges but for CARDINAL also considered that they lacked impartiality . The case was therefore submitted to ORG on DATE .
On DATE ORG transferred the case to ORG in PERSON . The latter court received the file from ORG in PERSON on DATE . ORG decision was served on the parties on DATE .
On DATE ORG asked all judges of the Košice II District Court to state whether or not they considered themselves biased . Statements of CARDINAL judges of ORG were submitted to ORG in GPE on DATE .
On DATE ORG in PERSON ordered ORG to determine the applicant ’s action . That decision was served on the parties in DATE . The file was transmitted to ORG in GPE on DATE .

On DATE ORG judge involved stated that he considered himself biased . Subsequently the other judges of that court made a statement to the same effect on the ground that they knew the defendant or his new partner .
On DATE ORG sent the file back to ORG in PERSON . On DATE ORG excluded CARDINAL ORG judges from dealing with the case . The file was returned to ORG in GPE on DATE .
In the course of DATE ORG obtained information about income of the applicant ’s parents .

On DATE ORG appointed a guardian to represent the interests of the applicant in the proceedings . On DATE it heard the applicant ’s mother . After it had obtained further evidence , ORG heard the defendant and the applicant on DATE .

On DATE ORG granted in part the applicant ’s action . The applicant , who reached full age in the meantime , appealed on DATE . On DATE the defendant submitted his observations in reply to the appeal . The file was transmitted to ORG on DATE .

After it had obtained further evidence ORG , on DATE , quashed the first instance judgment and instructed ORG to take further evidence . The decision stated that ORG had failed to establish all relevant facts correctly . It was served on the applicant on DATE .
In DATE ORG obtained new evidence . It heard the applicant and her mother on DATE . Further information concerning the situation of the parties was obtained in the course of DATE and in DATE .

At a hearing held on DATE the applicant requested that further evidence should be taken concerning the situation of the defendant . The relevant information was submitted to ORG in DATE . ORG also requested a third court to hear the defendant . The defendant was heard on DATE .
On DATE ORG delivered a new judgment on the merits in which it increased the maintenance to which the applicant was entitled .
On DATE the defendant appealed . On DATE ORG ordered the defendant to complete his appeal . The applicant submitted her observations in reply on DATE . On DATE the case was transmitted to ORG .

On DATE the file was sent back to ORG as a date in the operative part of its judgment had to be corrected . That shortcoming was remedied on DATE , and the amended decision was served on the parties on CARDINAL and DATE respectively .
DATE the file was examined by ORG to whom the applicant had filed a complaint in the meantime .
On DATE ORG upheld the first instance decision on the merits of the case . ORG further ordered ORG to adjudicate anew on the costs of the proceedings .
On DATE ORG asked the applicant ’s lawyer to specify the costs . The lawyer replied on DATE . In DATE ORG asked for further information on the matter . The information was submitted to it on DATE .
ORG decided on the costs of the proceedings on DATE . The defendant appealed on DATE .
On DATE ORG modified the first instance decision on the parties’ costs .
On DATE the applicant filed a complaint to the ORG pursuant to LAW . She alleged , inter alia , a violation of her right to a hearing without undue delay by a tribunal established by law .

On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s complaint . As regards the applicant ’s complaint that her right to a hearing by a tribunal established by law had been violated , ORG found that the applicant had not challenged the composition of the court which determined her action by means of an appeal against ORG judgment of DATE .

As regards the alleged violation of the applicant ’s right to a hearing without undue delay , the decision stated that LAW , ORG and ORG had finished dealing with the case before the applicant filed her complaint to ORG on DATE . The relevant part of her complaint was therefore manifestly ill - founded .

ORG further held that ORG had delivered its judgment on the merits on DATE , that is prior to introduction of the applicant ’s complaint under LAW , and that it could not further deal with the case as the appellate court had upheld that judgment . ORG therefore found no link permitting it to entertain the applicant ’s complaint to the extent that it concerned the length of the proceedings before ORG .
Finally , ORG decision stated that ORG had decided on the applicant ’s appeal on DATE , that is after DATE . The length of the proceedings before ORG was therefore not excessive .
Article CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides , inter alia , that every person has the right to have his or her case tried without unjustified delay .

Pursuant to Article CARDINAL ) of the LAW , as in force until DATE , ORG could commence proceedings upon a petition ( “ podnet ” ) presented by any individual or a corporation claiming that their rights had been violated . According to its case - law under former LAW ) of LAW , the Constitutional Court lacked jurisdiction to draw legal consequences from a violation of a petitioner ’s rights under LAW ) of the LAW . It could neither grant damages to the person concerned nor impose a sanction on the public authority liable for the violation found . In ORG view , it was therefore for the authority concerned to provide redress to the person whose rights were violated .

As from DATE , the LAW has been amended in that , inter alia , individuals and legal persons can complain about a violation of their fundamental rights and freedoms pursuant to LAW . Under this provision ORG has the power , in the event that it finds a violation of Article CARDINAL ) of the LAW , to order the authority concerned to proceed with the case without delay . It may also grant adequate financial satisfaction to the person whose constitutional rights have been violated as a result of excessive length of proceedings ( for further details see , e.g. , ORG and Others v. GPE ( dec . ) , nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL , PERSON , DATE , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE ) .
